ALLEGATION:
On 5/15/20 Staff 1 did not follow the facility's restraint protocol. Staff 1 singularly
physically restrained Resident A, so Resident A could not walk out the door.
INVESTIGATION:
On 5/19/2020 I reviewed the facility’s incident report dated 5/15/2020 for 5:35pm,
completed by Staff 1 and signed off by supervisors on 5/15/2020 (all signatures were
not legible) and Administrator B on 5/18/2020. The incident report indicated the
following:
 Resident A requested to speak to a supervisor and Staff 1 told Program
Supervisor 1 of the request. Staff 1 told Resident A of the consequences if he
did not comply with study hall guidelines. Resident A said, “I’ll take the day.”
Resident A walked out the “slate room” and went toward the exit. Staff 1 got
in front of Resident A, stopping Resident A’s movement. Resident A went the
other way and tried to walk out the kitchen exit. Resident A’s hand touched
the exit and Staff 1 secured Resident A until Supervisor 3 assisted with CPI
(Crisis Prevention Intervention). Resident A appeared as if he was trying to
truant.
 A “Narrative (Triggers & De-escalation) section that indicated: Resident A
“wanted to control the situation and be disrespectful towards staff”. Resident
A calmed down after talking with Program Supervisor 1.
 The nurse was notified.
Due to COVID-19, an on-site visit did not occur. I interviewed Administrator B and
Program Supervisor 1 via telephone on 5/20/2020. Email contact also occurred with
Administrator B.
3

Administrator B did not witness the incident. She reviewed the incident report and
spoke with staff. She provided me a copy of the incident report. Administrator B
reported the AIM’s program is an open program, but residents are not just allowed to
walk off. Nor are they automatically restrained for attempting to AWOL. The
situation of safety and risk of harm to the resident must be assessed to determine a
need for physical intervention. She indicated, in this instance, from all accounts,
Resident A was not trying to AWOL. Resident A was trying to reach Program
Supervisor 1 to talk to him; and Program Supervisor 1 was just outside the facility’s
door. Staff 1’s action and reaction in the situation was not in a manner as trained in
CPI. Additionally, Staff 1 did not immediately disengage with Resident A when
supervisors advised him to do so.
Administrator B reported Staff 1’s date of hire as 11/16/2017. Staff 1 completed
initial CPI module training, as well as, refresher training on 6/7/2018, and 6/12/2019;
and other CPI modules on 6/6/2018, 6/12/2019 and 3/20/2020. Staff 1 had one
disciplinary action on 8/3/2018 related to resident supervision with respect to a
resident self-harming incident. Staff 1 could tell the youth was doing something but
did not investigate.
Program Supervisor 1 affirmed Administrator B’s reporting pertaining his location
and Resident A’s pursuit to reach him when the incident happened. Program
Supervisor 1 also reported the facility utilizes CPI for its behavior management and
physical intervention systems. He reported, they try not to engage with physical
intervention if possible. In regard to this incident, he was not certain that physical
intervention was warranted. He advised he was conversating with Supervisor 2 and
Supervisor 3 when the incident was occurring. He did not hear all, and did not know
whether Staff 1 tried to de-escalate Resident A. He only knew, heard at the point
Resident A kicked on the door; and he, Supervisor 3 and Supervisor 2 became
involved in the physical intervention. As to the complaint indicating Resident A was
restrained and taken to the floor so Resident A would not walk out the door and
escape. Program Supervisor 1 denied Resident A being taken to the floor; and he
did not believe Resident A was trying to escape. Staff 1 had Resident A was up
against a wall; and after Program Supervisor 1 and the other two supervisors
intervened, he advised Staff 1 to end the restraint. Program Supervisor 1 reported
there were five residents, at the time of incident. He did not know which residents
may have witnessed the incident.
Due to COVID-19, I interviewed Resident A(age14), Resident B (age 14), Resident
C (age 15), Resident D (age 11) and Resident E (age 15) via Facetime on
5/20/2020.
Resident A denied an attempt to AWOL. He just wanted to talk with the supervisor.
He explained that he was called out of study time, by his counselor, to make a
telephone call. Following the ten-minute telephone call, Resident A went into the
facility’s “slate room” (A room where residents go for quiet time). He was followed at
some point by Staff 1. Staff 1 advised him he needed to either finished up his study
4

hour of take a consequence for missing it. Resident A said, he had completed ten
minutes of the study hour and Staff 1 wanted him to complete the full hour.
Resident A initially agreed to take the consequence but thought about it, then said
no to the consequence. Staff 1 then told him he could complete 45-minutes, of the
remaining study hour. Resident A asked to speak with Program Supervisor 1 and
Staff 1 said he would talk with Program Supervisor 2 about the matter. Resident A
also asked Staff 2 to call the supervisor. Staff 2 said she would, and that she did
contact Program Supervisor 1. Resident A reported, he was concerned with talking
to Program Supervisor 2 promptly, because of the time. It was around 3:15pm and
Program Supervisor 1 would leave at 3:30pm. Resident A saw through the window
that Program Supervisor 1 was outside. He asked to go talk with him and proceeded
to walk to the door. Staff 1 grabbed Resident A’s arm and restrained him against the
door. Program Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, and Supervisor 3 intervened and
Program Supervisor 1 told Staff 1 to let him go. Resident A said he was never
taken to the floor; and he did not receive any injuries. He denied a prior negative
relationship with Staff 1. He just thought he should not have been restrained or given
a consequence for being taken out of study hour to make call to his parent.
Resident B reported, Resident A went to the “slate” after making a call to his mom.
Then Staff 1 was talking to Resident A and gave Resident A a day of restrictive
privileges (less participation in some activities and ‘dining details such as washing
dishes, mopping, doing table, etc.) for missing the whole hour of study hour.
Resident B did not think that was normal. He affirmed Resident A’s reporting of
what Resident A wanted to do with respects to talking to a supervisor; and them
observing the supervisors outside. Resident B said, Resident A tried to walk out one
door and Staff 1 held him back. Then Resident A tried to go out the kitchen door and
Staff 1 restrained Resident A. The restraint was a normal restraint. Staff 1 held
Resident A in between the pantry wall and where they put the dishes. Resident A
was cursing and telling Staff 1 “to get the fuck off me”; and called Staff 1 the “N” and
“B” word. Staff 1 told Resident A “No I’m not getting off you until you calm down.”.
The supervisors heard the call for assistance by Staff 2 and they intervened.
Resident C reported observing the restraint, which he thought looked normal in
comparison to other restraints he had observed. He said, Resident A was trying to
walk out the door to talk to supervisors and Staff 1 grabbed both of Resident A’s
arms to place behind Resident A ‘s back. Staff 1 hooked his arms behind Resident A
and restrained Resident A. Resident A was cursing, and Staff 1 was not saying
anything.
Resident D did not recall the incident. Resident D said all the restraints he had
witnessed have been proper.
Resident E did not have information about the incident. He said, he was taking a
shower and did not witness the incident.
5

Staff 2 was interviewed by me via telephone on 5/26/2020. She acknowledged
awareness of the incident. Staff 1 was her partner for that afternoon shift; and
Resident A was assigned to Staff 1. Staff 2 thought something usual was happening
between Staff 1 and Resident A but she was not certain of what that was. She
noticed that Staff 1 did not respond to Staff 3(who was ending his shift) when Staff 3
asked Staff 1 whether Resident A could have carrots. Staff 1 was right there, but
never responded. Staff 2 advised when a resident is assigned to another staff, they
try not to intervene for that staff. However, since Staff 1 did not respond to Staff 3,
she did by saying, yes.
Staff 2 reported at some point Case Coordinator 4 came for Resident A, indicating
Resident A had a Zoom meeting with family. Afterwards, Resident A sat in the slate
room with his books, but then came and reported to Staff 1 he would take the one
day of “RP” (Restricted Privileges). Staff 2 did not know when Staff 1 gave the “RP”.
She heard Resident A agreeing to the “RP”, then taking it back. Resident A said he
was not taking “RP” for talking with his mother. Afterward, between 3:00pm -
3:15pm, Staff 1 and Resident A talked. Staff 1 did not hear that conservation, but a
few minutes later Resident A kept asking to talk with Program Supervisor 1.
Resident A said, it was not fair that he be punished for talking to his mom. Resident
A stood up, and Resident A motioned as if he was going to run to the door. Staff 1
stood up in front of Resident A. Resident A was loud, cursing Staff 1 and tried to
push pass Staff 1. The two were touching and Staff 1 was directing Resident A
back. Staff 2 intervened verbally, calling Resident A’s name, so as to get him to calm
down. Resident A then said, “You don’t want me to go this way; I’ll go another way”,
and Resident A walked toward the dining area door. Resident A was yelling for
Program Supervisor 1. Staff 2 tried, to signal Program Supervisor 1 with her finger
via the window, but he did not see her. She was going behind Resident A, to let him
talk with Program Supervisor 1 but Staff 1 ran behind Resident A. Staff 1 grabbed
Resident A by the back of Resident A’s shirt, and then restrained Resident A. At
one-point Resident A was in the air, he had been lifted off the floor. Staff 2 surmised
that happened because Staff 1 tried to pick Resident A up to put Resident A in the
restraint. Staff 2 said Staff 1 may have also held Resident A up against a door or
something. She was not sure of what, because by that time she was getting the
other residents moved and calling for assistance. She recalled Resident A saying let
me go “Mother Fucker; and he tried to throw a blow. The supervisors intervened
and took Resident A outside.
Staff 2 reported Staff 1’s action was not the proper way. She said Staff 1 is
approximately, 6’2’’ and Resident A 5’2’’ or 5’3’’ and the proper way would have
been to secure the resident’s arm or wrist, then contact someone for assistance to
get the resident into the proper restraint hold, so the resident could calm down. Staff
1 did not do that. She said, Resident A does not like Staff 1; and Staff 1 and
Resident A were both heated. Resident A was really irate and calling Staff 1 names.
Resident A called Staff 1 a “Bitch ass nigga” and Staff 1 said, “What you gonna do
about it”. Staff 2 said, once Resident A escalated, nothing she heard from Staff 1
was de-escalating. She said the facility’s overall standard is if the child escalates, to
6

talk them down, to deescalate; to restrain as a last resort. She reported the
punishment given Resident A likely escalated him and she would not have given the
consequence. She said, when Resident A gets upset, Resident A can work through
it pretty quickly with assistance.
Supervisor 2 and Supervisor 3 were interviewed by me via separate telephone calls
on 5/26/2020. Both were outside of the door with Program Supervisor 1 when the
incident occurred. It was shift change and Supervisor 2, who was departing the
facility, was filling the other two supervisors in on the outcome of the first shift. At
some point Resident A tried to get Program Supervisor 1’s attention. Supervisor 3
saw Resident A motioning to Program Supervisor 1 prior to the door opening.
Supervisor 3 questioned what had happened so quickly.
Supervisor 2 and Supervisor 3 reported as they came by the dining room door,
Resident A yelled to Program Supervisor 1. Supervisor 2 said Resident A slammed
the door open and Staff 1 grabbed Resident A around the upper torso, under the
arm and pulled Resident A back inside. He, said, Program Supervisor 1 and
Supervisor 3 got to the door quicker than he. When Supervisor 2 got inside Staff 1
had Resident A up against a door in the dining area. Resident A was screaming for
Program Supervisor 1 to have Staff 1 let him go. Program Supervisor 1 told Staff 1
to release Resident A. It took a second request from Program Supervisor 1 for Staff
1 to release Resident A. Resident A told them Resident A was mad over being given
a consequence for missing study hall, which occurred due to him being pulled away
for a telephone call. Supervisor 2 reported what he observed was not CPI protocol.
He said, that even inside to restraint the resident up against the wall as a single
person was not proper. He was not sure, if Staff 1 thought Resident A was running
way, but what he (Supervisor 2) saw was not related to CPI protocol for handling
such. He affirmed Administrator B’s reporting related to Staff 1’s employment time
and CPI training.
Supervisor 3 saw Resident A pulled backward when the dining room door opened.
He said, the voices did not sound right, they were loud. He called to Program
Supervisor 1 and they entered immediately. Staff 1 had Resident A up against the
dishwasher. Resident A’s voice was elevated, and he was trying to get loose.
Program Supervisor 1 told Staff 1 twice to let Resident A go. Supervisor 3 wasn’t
sure whether Staff 1’s delayed in releasing Resident A was perhaps because Staff 1
didn’t hear the first instruction. Supervisor 3 and Program Supervision 1 put their
arm on Resident A to calm him down. Supervisor 3 also mentioned Staff 1’s height.
He said Staff is a “tall guy” and Program Supervisor 1 had observed Staff 1’s arm
was near Resident A’s neck and Program Supervisor 1 wanted Staff 1 to let go.
Supervisor 3 said he was positioned on the other side of Program Supervisor 1, so
he did not see that. Supervisor 3 observed Staff 1’s face. Staff 1 seemed frustrated
and agitated. Supervisor 3 spoke with Staff 1 to find out what happened. Staff 1
reported when Resident A touched the door, it was a truancy situation; he (Staff 1)
thought Resident A was going to run. Supervisor 3 did not perceive that to be true.
Supervisor 3 said, “we’ were right outside the door”. Staff 1 “could see us”. He said
7

Resident A has a good relationship with Program Supervisor 1 and that would have
been why Resident A was seeking Program Supervisor 1’s assistance. He said,
even if Resident A was trying to truant, staff should “still try to talk to and deescalate”
the resident, “not grab the resident”, especially if no other staff are nearby. The staff
should also call for assistance. Supervisor 3 reported facility policy does not allow for
a one-person restraint, unless in an extremely circumstance, which this was not. He
said, Staff 1 usually has a good relationship with residents, but Staff 1 “can be
impatient and that appeared in play that day” of the incident.
Staff 1 was interviewed by me via telephone on 5/28/2020. He reported being
employed with the AIM program for 30 months and to completing initial CPI training
at hire and refresher training in 2019. He reported physical management being able
to occur in staff boundary situations, attempted escapes, peer fights, and resident
self-harming. He acknowledged his involvement in the incident with Resident A,
and to him writing the incident report. Staff 1 reported the incident occurred between
3-4:00pm.
Sometime after Staff 1 arrived on shift, Resident A asked Staff 1 the location of the
other staff. Resident A went out his way to not speak with Staff 1; to engage with
Staff 2, not him (Staff 1). They were in study time, and prior to study hour ending
Resident A asked to speak with Program Supervisor 1 about going home. Later
Resident A asked to speak with Program Supervisor 1 about getting out of study
hour, saying “I’m not trying to study now”. Staff 1 affirmed Staff 2’s reporting related
to Case Coordinator 4 retrieving Resident A from the group for a telephone call and
Resident A going to the slate thereafter. Resident A was gone 15-20 minutes. The
study group was approximately 45 minutes into the study hour but during that time
Resident A was eating a snack and lollygagging around. Resident A did not want to
do the study time. Staff 1 followed Resident A into the slate room to talk with him.
Resident A did not have pen or paper and was not studying. Staff 1 advised
Resident A that Resident A still had to do a study hour within the shift time. Resident
A asked, “you are giving me an hour for talking with by mama”. Staff 1 then advised
Resident A to just give him 45 minutes and Resident A would not get a
consequence. After finding out the consequence would be one day of “RP”,
Resident A first agreed to it. Resident A then changed his mind. Resident A said,
“No. I’m not taking no fucking day for talking with my mama”. Staff 1 explained to
Resident A, he (Resident A) did not have to take the day. Resident A could just do
the study time. Resident A asked to speak with Program Supervisor 1 and repeated
his prior statement about not taking the “RP” day. Resident A asked Staff 2 where
was Program Supervisor 1; and Staff 2 advised Resident A, Program Supervisor 1
was outside. Staff 2 asked Resident A to calm down, to sit down and told him she
would get Program Supervisor 1. Resident A did not comply. Resident A walked to
the door and Staff 1 stepped in front of Resident A. Resident A told him, “don’t
fucking touch me. I said, I’m not.” Resident A proceeded to walk toward the kitchen
door; and Staff 1 followed. Staff 1 tried to step in front of Resident A again when
Resident A opened the door. Staff 1, said, “I pulled him back in to try to stop him
from truanting. I held him against the wall until assistance came.” I asked Staff 1 if
8

he was certain, Resident A was trying to truant or whether Resident A was just trying
to get to Program Supervisor 1, whom Resident A and he both knew was outside the
door. Staff 1 reported, in his mind, since he had told Resident A to not go out the
door, that meant Resident A was trying to truant. Staff 1 acknowledged truancy was
not a part of Resident A’s history. Nor had Resident A, in the 10 months Resident A
had resided at the facility tried to truant. However, Staff 1 still thought Resident A
was trying to AWOL. He reported policy indicates if a resident is trying to truant, the
staff should call for assistance over their walkie talkie and do your best to stop the
resident. Staff 1 advised that is done if they are not in close proximately to the
youth, but he was. He admitted CPI does not allow for a one-person restraint. It
calls for a two-person restraint. He said “I didn’t really restraint him. I just secured
him and held him against the wall until assistance arrived”. He said, he had his arms
around Resident A’s arms to make sure Resident A did not hit him and that they
were both safe. He said, Resident A was flailing his arms and Resident A tried to
push off the wall. He, said, Staff 2 called for assistance; called a “Code 2”, meaning
an irate resident or one doing something they should not be doing. Staff 2 was also
securing the other residents. Supervisor 2, Supervisor 3, and Program Supervisor 1
arrived, and Supervisor 3 assisted in the restraint. They placed Resident A in a two-
person restraint until Program Supervisor 1 said to release Resident A. Program
Supervisor 1 only made one request for Resident A to be release. Staff 1 said,
Program Supervisor 1’s release directive was not directed to him in particular, it was
just letting him and Supervisor 3 both know to release the youth, and they did so.
Staff 1 reported during the time he was holding Resident A, Resident A was cursing,
saying he hated him, calling him the derogatory name as reported by Staff 2. Staff 1
was not saying anything. He stated that, “in those moments, they tell us not to
speak, so as to not make the incident worst”. He denied pulling Resident A off the
floor. He pulled Resident A back from the door but, “It wasn’t aggressive.” He said, “I
wrapped my arms around him and pulled him back. I put one arm forward on each
side of him to secure him.” He said, he never had an incident like that, that no
resident had truanted on him. Staff 1 acknowledged he had an option to allow
Resident A to proceed to Program Supervisor 1 while Staff 1 stayed in close
proximately to Resident A. Staff 1 reported had Resident A complied to the earlier
requests, Resident A would not have needed supervisor assistance. Staff 1
surmised that Resident A was likely mad with him at the beginning of the shift. He
said, he tried to work with Resident A. He tried to talk with and deescalate Resident
A earlier on in the incident. He said, his action earlier was to give Resident A
options. He said, to him Resident A was looking for a reason to act out.
Resident B, Staff 1, Staff 2, Program Supervisor 1, Supervisor 2, and Supervisor 3
did not observe injuries or marks to Resident A after the incident. Supervisor 2 and
Supervisor 3 also both reported Resident A did not report any marks or bruises.
Reviewed:
 Incident report as reported earlier within this report.
9

 Documentation showing Resident A is a temporary court ward, who was
placed at the facility on 6/30/2019.
 The facility’s Staff-to resident supervision policy.
 Nursing note, that indicated Resident A was assessed at 4:45pm on
5/15/2020. Resident A denied injuries and was not assessed to have any.
He had full range of motion of his arms and hands, and he was ambulatory.
 The facility’s restraint Policy, which indicated:
o All resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is safe,
appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the minor child’s
behavior, chronological and developmental age, size, gender, physical
condition, medical condition, psychiatric condition, and personal history
including any history of trauma and done in a manner consist with the
resident’s treatment plan. Youths will not be transported until/unless
they have deescalated and are able to cooperate with the transport.
Youths are to be deescalated and therapeutic rapport established in
their program unit by core team members or Youth Specialist following
acting out episodes.
o Resident restraint may only be performed by staff members who have
successfully completed training in Non-Crisis Intervention as provided
by certified trainers. Specifically, each staff member must successfully
complete 2-day Crisis Prevention Institute training upon their hire.
Annual refresher training is then required every year thereafter.
o Resident restraint is only permitted under the following circumstances:
-To prevent injury to the child, self-injury, or injury to others.
-As a precaution against escape or truancy.
-When there is serious destruction of property that places a child or
others at serious threat of violence or injury if no intervention occurs.
 Video footage, via facetime, which showed:
o A youth identified as Resident A walking and come to a door. As
Resident A went toward the door and as he opened it, a staff identified
as Staff 1 quickly yanked or pulled Resident A backward, in an
assertive manner.
o Staff 1 pulled Resident A to a corner/ area across from a stove, where
a sink, dish washer and cabinet are seen.
o Staff 1 had Resident 1 against that area. Resident A appeared to be
struggling.
o Shortly thereon, other staff, identified as the prior stated supervisors
enter.
o I was unable to see all action by Staff 1 or the supervisors. The
incident was very quick.
10

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.159 Resident restraint.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written policies
and procedures regarding restraints. These policies and
procedures shall be available to all residents, their families,
and referring agencies.
(2) Resident restraint shall be performed in a manner that is
safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity of the
minor child’s behavior, chronological and developmental
age, size, gender, physical condition, medical condition,
psychiatric condition, and personal history, including any
history of trauma, and done in a manner consistent with the
resident’s treatment plan.
ANALYSIS: The evident showed:
 The facility’s supervisory staff and Staff 1 reported that
CPI is the behavior management system used by the
facility. Both confirmed that Staff 1 was trained in CPI.
 Staff 1 perceived Resident A’s action to go out the door
to seek Program Supervisor 1’s intervention in his’ and
Staff 1’s dispute as defiance and an attempt to truant
when it was clear, Resident A was not trying to AWOL.
 Staff 1 responded to Resident A’s upset, and subsequent
verbal disparagement of him by following Resident A,
then grabbing Resident A in an assertive manner, lifting
him off the floor. Staff 1’ s actions further escalated
Resident A; and Staff 1 stopped efforts to try to
deescalate Resident A as required by CPI.
 Staff 1 did not follow CPI protocol. He did not seek
supervisory intervention to try to further deescalate
Resident A or engage Resident A in intervention to allow
Resident A access to the supervisor so as to aid in
deescalating Resident A.
11

 Staff 1 restrained Resident A in a one-person restraint,
which is against the facility’s CPI protocol.
 The restraint was not proportionate to the severity of
Resident A’s behavior. Resident A was not trying to
AWOL. Additionally, the restraint was not performance in
a safe manner. Staff 1’s arm was near Resident A’s neck
and Program Supervisor 1 directed Staff 1 to release
Resident A from the restraint.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the facility’s
current licensing status is recommended.
July 13, 2020
